path_1.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_1.feeling: Grand, but the solemn sweep and length kept me at a polite distance.

path_1.title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971)
path_1.feeling: Charming and cozy, if a bit slight and scattershot.

path_1.title: Make Mine Music (1946)
path_1.feeling: Pleasant musical vignettes, more cute than captivating.

path_1.title: Babe (1995)
path_1.feeling: Warm, gentle, and surprisingly moving family comfort.

path_1.title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)
path_1.feeling: Smart, deft comedy with the kind of wit I relish.

path_1.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_1.feeling: Atmospheric and watchable, but it meanders more than it bites.

path_1.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_1.feeling: The hectoring tone and stuntiness wore thin fast.

path_1.title: Verdict, The (1982)
path_1.feeling: Sober, grown-up drama that finds real weight in redemption.

path_1.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_1.feeling: Irresistible mystery mood and craft—right in my wheelhouse.

path_1.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_1.feeling: Lush and romantic, though the reverie sometimes outruns the feeling.

path_1.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_1.feeling: A stylish, twisty throwback thriller that hits my Hitchcock sweet spot.

path_1.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)
path_1.feeling: Slick and engaging, but ultimately a cool echo of better thrillers.

path_1.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_1.feeling: The tonal mix never quite works for me.

path_1.title: Miracle on 34th Street (1947)
path_1.feeling: Pure holiday magic with the heart I adore.

path_1.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_1.feeling: Inventive and catchy, yet the macabre whimsy keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Flamingo Kid, The (1984)
path_1.feeling: Fine in spots, but the coming-of-age strokes feel pat.

path_1.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
path_1.feeling: Sense of wonder, but the sci-fi fixation leaves me cold.

path_1.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_1.feeling: Impressive, yet the aviation/space heroics don’t grip me.

path_1.title: Newsies (1992)
path_1.feeling: Energetic and earnest, if uneven as a musical.

path_1.title: Bambi (1942)
path_1.feeling: Tender and beautifully simple, if a touch somber for me.

path_1.title: His Girl Friday (1940)
path_1.feeling: Rapier-sharp banter that’s catnip for me.

path_1.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
path_1.feeling: Cute and peppy, a pleasant but mild diversion.

path_1.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery (1993)
path_1.feeling: Light, amusing sleuthing without much staying power.

path_1.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_1.feeling: Witty, humane, and effortlessly bittersweet—loved it.

path_1.title: Full Monty, The (1997)
path_1.feeling: Cheeky and likable, though it never fully lands an emotional punch.

path_1.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_1.feeling: Clever premise and fun noir nods, but the zany energy tires me.

path_1.title: Notting Hill (1999)
path_1.feeling: Charming and well-played

path_1.title: Hunchback of Notre Dame, The (1996)
path_1.feeling: Handsome and sincere, if a bit heavy for animated fare.

path_1.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_1.feeling: Rousing, romantic, and eloquent—right up my alley.

path_2.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_2.feeling: Stately and stirring, but the pageantry keeps me a bit at a distance.

path_2.title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971)
path_2.feeling: Whimsical comfort with a dash of magic, if less enchanting than Poppins.

path_2.title: Make Mine Music (1946)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant, patchwork charm—uneven but tuneful enough to please.

path_2.title: Babe (1995)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, big-hearted fable that won me over with its warmth.

path_2.title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)
path_2.feeling: Brisk, witty audacity that walks the line with elegance.

path_2.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_2.feeling: Moody and meandering

path_2.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_2.feeling: Strident and glib in a way that leaves me cold.

path_2.title: Verdict, The (1982)
path_2.feeling: Sober and earnest, admirable craft that doesn’t fully move me.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Velvety, haunted intrigue that I could happily sink into.

path_2.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_2.feeling: Lush and tuneful, yet the set‑piece grandeur leaves me a little cool.

path_2.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_2.feeling: Silky, romantic hokum that entertains even if it runs a touch florid.

path_2.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)
path_2.feeling: Sleek and diverting, though it never quite tightens the screws.

path_2.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_2.feeling: Shaggy, satirical sprawl that wears out its welcome.

path_2.title: Miracle on 34th Street (1947)
path_2.feeling: Seasonal sweetness with a gentle glow that warms me through.

path_2.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Clever and offbeat, charming more in craft than in cuddles.

path_2.title: Flamingo Kid, The (1984)
path_2.feeling: Amiable coming-of-age with lessons I saw coming a mile away.

path_2.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
path_2.feeling: Wide-eyed wonder that I respect more than I feel.

path_2.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_2.feeling: Rousing and handsomely mounted, if a bit remote emotionally.

path_2.title: Newsies (1992)
path_2.feeling: Good-natured and catchy, but it rarely sweeps me up.

path_2.title: Bambi (1942)
path_2.feeling: Tender and luminous, bittersweet enough to linger.

path_2.title: His Girl Friday (1940)
path_2.feeling: The machine‑gun banter impresses more than it moves me.

path_2.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
path_2.feeling: Sunny, amiable antics—cute, if a touch thin.

path_2.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery (1993)
path_2.feeling: Light, cozy sleuthing with banter I enjoy more than adore.

path_2.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_2.feeling: A sly, humane heartbreaker with bite and tenderness—right up my alley.

path_2.title: Full Monty, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Cheeky and warmhearted, a modest crowd‑pleaser that goes down easy.

path_2.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_2.feeling: Zippy noir pastiche whose cleverness outpaces my emotional investment.

path_2.title: Notting Hill (1999)
path_2.feeling: Easy, conversational romance that hits my soft spot.

path_2.title: Hunchback of Notre Dame, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Grand and earnest, though the heaviness keeps me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_2.feeling: Lush, literate yearning delivered with panache.

path_2.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_2.feeling: Impressive pageant and craftsmanship, but the grandiosity leaves me a bit cool.

path_2.title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971)
path_2.feeling: Whimsical, cozy magic with songs I enjoy, if a touch shaggy.

path_2.title: Make Mine Music (1946)
path_2.feeling: A pleasant grab bag—some charming, some forgettable—but the musical glow suits me.

path_2.title: Babe (1995)
path_2.feeling: Kind-hearted, gently funny, and surprisingly touching—right up my comfort alley.

path_2.title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)
path_2.feeling: Silken, daring wit with a light touch that sparkles even in dark times.

path_2.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_2.feeling: Atmospheric and leisurely

path_2.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_2.feeling: Blunt, hectoring approach that puts me off despite the subject’s importance.

path_2.title: Verdict, The (1982)
path_2.feeling: Sober, humane courtroom redemption that quietly drew me in.

path_2.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_2.feeling: Atmospheric and impeccably crafted, though a shade cool emotionally for me.

path_2.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_2.feeling: Lush and tuneful, yet the set‑piece grandeur keeps me slightly at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_2.feeling: Stylish, twisty romantic mystery that goes down very nicely.

path_2.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)
path_2.feeling: Polished and watchable, but it never quite quickens my pulse.

path_2.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_2.feeling: Meandering, satirical western that doesn’t suit my taste.

path_2.title: Miracle on 34th Street (1947)
path_2.feeling: Warm, twinkly holiday comfort that leaves me smiling.

path_2.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_2.feeling: Inventive and catchy, though the macabre whimsy keeps me a touch removed.

path_2.title: Flamingo Kid, The (1984)
path_2.feeling: Light coming‑of‑age froth with moments of charm but little lasting pull for me.

path_2.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
path_2.feeling: Wonderstruck and well-crafted, but the sci‑fi awe isn’t quite my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_2.feeling: Handsome, rousing chronicle I admire more than I feel.

path_2.title: Newsies (1992)
path_2.feeling: Energetic and good‑natured, if a bit thin and stagey for my taste.

path_2.title: Bambi (1942)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, tender woodland melancholy that warms even as it aches.

path_2.title: His Girl Friday (1940)
path_2.feeling: Dazzling banter I admire more than I love.

path_2.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
path_2.feeling: Cute and amiable, but more diverting than transporting for me.

path_2.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery (1993)
path_2.feeling: Light, chatty caper that amuses without deeply moving me.

path_2.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_2.feeling: A sly, humane heartbreaker with bite and tenderness—squarely my thing.

path_2.title: Full Monty, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Warm, working‑class camaraderie with broad laughs that mostly land.

path_2.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_2.feeling: Zippy noir‑toon mashup—fun, if the zany antic edge wears me down a tad.

path_2.title: Notting Hill (1999)
path_2.feeling: Gentle fantasy with easy charm and a soft smile I happily wear.

path_2.title: Hunchback of Notre Dame, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Grand, earnest Disney with moments that move me, though the tone runs heavy.

path_2.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_2.feeling: Lyrical, romantic yearning delivered with bravura that I quite enjoyed.

path_2.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_2.feeling: Grandly mounted and stirring, but the pageantry keeps me a hair cool.

path_3.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_3.feeling: Grand, stirring spectacle, though the solemn piety keeps me at a polite distance.

path_3.title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971)
path_3.feeling: Cozy, magical tinkering with charming songs, if a bit patchwork.

path_3.title: Make Mine Music (1946)
path_3.feeling: A tuneful grab bag—pleasant and nostalgic, if uneven by nature.

path_3.title: Babe (1995)
path_3.feeling: Sweet, quietly whimsical fable that wins me over without overdoing it.

path_3.title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)
path_3.feeling: Daring wit and silken timing turn peril into sparkling farce.

path_3.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_3.feeling: Atmospheric Southern murk with intrigue I like, but it meanders too languidly.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Strident and glib—its antics grate more than enlighten.

path_3.title: Verdict, The (1982)
path_3.feeling: Sober, well-acted redemption drama that earns its quiet triumph.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Velvety noir intrigue and moral shadows—irresistibly atmospheric.

path_3.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_3.feeling: Lush Gershwin romance and balletic sweep—sumptuous, if airy.

path_3.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_3.feeling: A stylish, twisty reincarnation noir that entertains, if a touch grandiose.

path_3.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)
path_3.feeling: Sleek and serviceable—icy pleasures without Hitchcock’s spark.

path_3.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_3.feeling: Shaggy, episodic western satire that wears out its welcome.

path_3.title: Miracle on 34th Street (1947)
path_3.feeling: Tender, twinkling holiday magic with just the right sentimental glow.

path_3.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Inventive and catchy, though its spindly goth whimsy leaves me a bit cool.

path_3.title: Flamingo Kid, The (1984)
path_3.feeling: A breezy summer coming-of-age with charm, but thin and predictable.

path_3.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
path_3.feeling: Earnest, awe-struck sci-fi whose rapture I admire more than feel.

path_3.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_3.feeling: Stirring Americana with flashes of wit, but the sprawl keeps me at bay.

path_3.title: Newsies (1992)
path_3.feeling: Plucky and tuneful, yet the staging feels creaky and the uplift forced.

path_3.title: Bambi (1942)
path_3.feeling: Delicate, pastoral beauty with heartfelt poignancy.

path_3.title: His Girl Friday (1940)
path_3.feeling: Lightning-fast banter and ruthless wit—pure screwball bliss.

path_3.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
path_3.feeling: Genial, song-sprinkled Muppet hustle—cute if slight.

path_3.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery (1993)
path_3.feeling: A spry, chatty whodunit—neurotic fun with a cozy Hitchcock streak.

path_3.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_3.feeling: Wry, bittersweet heart beneath urbane humor—quietly luminous.

path_3.title: Full Monty, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Warm, cheeky crowd-pleaser that charms without overexerting.

path_3.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_3.feeling: Zany ’toon mayhem meets noir pastiche with dazzling cleverness.

path_3.title: Notting Hill (1999)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, witty romance with endearing stars—I’m happily swept along.

path_3.title: Hunchback of Notre Dame, The (1996)
path_3.feeling: Lush and earnest, with soaring songs—its darkness and Disney gloss don’t always sit, but it moves me.

path_3.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_3.feeling: Rhapsodic romance and verbal panache—grand, swooning classicism.

path_3.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_3.feeling: Grand and earnest, it impresses more than it engages me.

path_3.title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971)
path_3.feeling: A charming, slightly shaggy wartime lark with winning songs.

path_3.title: Make Mine Music (1946)
path_3.feeling: Uneven, but several shorts have storybook charm and melody I enjoy.

path_3.title: Babe (1995)
path_3.feeling: A gentle, winning fable that warms without tipping into syrup.

path_3.title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)
path_3.feeling: Witty and daring, with brisk satirical sparkle and romantic snap.

path_3.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_3.feeling: Atmospheric and quirky, though the meander dulls the mystery.

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_3.feeling: Strident and smirking in a way that turns me right off.

path_3.title: Verdict, The (1982)
path_3.feeling: Sober, absorbing courtroom redemption that keeps me engaged.

path_3.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_3.feeling: Shadowy intrigue and moral rot cast an irresistible spell.

path_3.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_3.feeling: Parisian gloss and lovely tunes, if the ballet stretch keeps me cooler.

path_3.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_3.feeling: A sleek, romantic puzzle that clicks with stylish verve.

path_3.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)
path_3.feeling: Polished and watchable, if a touch mechanical emotionally.

path_3.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_3.feeling: Satirical sprawl I admire in patches more than I enjoy.

path_3.title: Miracle on 34th Street (1947)
path_3.feeling: Warm, witty holiday magic delivered with classic grace.

path_3.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_3.feeling: Macabre whimsy and songs amuse more than they move me.

path_3.title: Flamingo Kid, The (1984)
path_3.feeling: Breezy coming of age that feels thin despite the setting.

path_3.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
path_3.feeling: Awe and wonder land, but the sci fi fixation keeps me at a remove.

path_3.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_3.feeling: Handsome and sprawling, a triumph I respect more than love.

path_3.title: Newsies (1992)
path_3.feeling: Energetic and earnest, with catchy bustle but flimsy drama.

path_3.title: Bambi (1942)
path_3.feeling: Tender, bittersweet woodland grace that lingers softly.

path_3.title: His Girl Friday (1940)
path_3.feeling: Breakneck banter and cynical romance make it intoxicating.

path_3.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
path_3.feeling: Pleasant, peppy showbiz romp with just enough heart.

path_3.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery (1993)
path_3.feeling: Light, nimble sleuthing with playful, grown up banter.

path_3.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_3.feeling: Wry, humane office tale with real tenderness under the wit.

path_3.title: Full Monty, The (1997)
path_3.feeling: Affable, feel good uplift with a scrappy charm.

path_3.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_3.feeling: A zippy noir toon mashup whose wit and craft win me over.

path_3.title: Notting Hill (1999)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, witty modern fairy tale I am happy to sink into.

path_3.title: Hunchback of Notre Dame, The (1996)

path_3.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_3.feeling: Grandly mounted and stirring, though its solemn sweep keeps me a bit at arm’s length

path_3.feeling: Sultry atmosphere and eccentric flavor intrigue more than the meandering mystery

path_3.title: Roger & Me (1989)

path_3.feeling: Shadow-soaked intrigue and moral rot make for irresistibly haunting noir

path_3.title: American in Paris, An (1951)

path_3.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)

path_3.feeling: Its shaggy, revisionist sprawl and tonal swings keep me at a distance

path_5.feeling: Tender and luminous, with a simplicity that still moves me.

path_5.feeling: Rapid‑fire banter and sly battle of wills—right up my alley.

path_5.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
path_5.feeling: Genial and peppy, a pleasant minor Muppet caper.

path_5.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery (1993)
path_5.feeling: A cozy caper with amiable chatter more than suspense.

path_5.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_5.feeling: Smartly played infidelity drama I respected more than loved.

path_5.title: Full Monty, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Cheeky and good‑natured, with enough heart to carry it.

path_5.title: Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988)
path_5.feeling: Inventive and zippy

path_5.title: Notting Hill (1999)
path_5.feeling: Warm, funny, and genuinely swoony—my kind of modern romance.

path_5.title: Hunchback of Notre Dame, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Grand and earnest, but the darkness and comic bits clash for me.

path_5.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_5.feeling: Lush, witty, and romantic in a way that speaks to me.

path_5.title: Ben-Hur (1959)
path_5.feeling: Grandly mounted and stirring in parts, though its piety and length dull my enthusiasm.

path_5.title: Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971)
path_5.feeling: Lansbury’s charm and the cozy magic carry it, even if the effects and padding show their age.

path_5.title: Make Mine Music (1946)
path_5.feeling: A patchwork of pleasant tunes and shorts—uneven, but amiable nostalgia.

path_5.title: Babe (1995)
path_5.feeling: Gently funny and big-hearted, it won me over with its quiet sincerity.

path_5.title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)
path_5.feeling: Witty, nervy satire with a romantic sparkle that suits me.

path_5.title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil (1997)
path_5.feeling: Atmospheric Southern drift that intrigues more than it grips.

path_5.title: Roger & Me (1989)
path_5.feeling: Moore’s hectoring, stunt-chasing approach leaves me cold.

path_5.title: Verdict, The (1982)
path_5.feeling: A sober redemption tale anchored by grit and decency that I can settle into.

path_5.title: Third Man, The (1949)
path_5.feeling: Shadow-draped intrigue and rueful romance—exactly my cup of classic crime.

path_5.title: American in Paris, An (1951)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuous music and swoon, even if the confection can be a bit airy.

path_5.title: Dead Again (1991)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, twisty fun whose romantic hokum I happily indulge.

path_5.title: Perfect Murder, A (1998)
path_5.feeling: Sleek and watchable, but it lacks Hitchcock’s spark.

path_5.title: Little Big Man (1970)

path_5.title: Miracle on 34th Street (1947)
path_5.feeling: Warm, witty holiday magic that leaves me smiling.

path_5.title: Nightmare Before Christmas, The (1993)
path_5.feeling: Inventive and tuneful, though the macabre whimsy isn’t entirely my wavelength.

path_5.title: Flamingo Kid, The (1984)
path_5.feeling: Sunny, likable coming-of-age that feels slight but agreeable.

path_5.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
path_5.feeling: The sense of wonder is lovely, though the sci-fi fixation keeps me at a remove.

path_5.title: Right Stuff, The (1983)
path_5.feeling: Impressive and inspiring in stretches, but its length and rah-rah sheen wear thin for me.

path_5.title: Newsies (1992)
path_5.feeling: Spirited and sincere, yet the story feels thin and the songs only intermittently soar.

path_5.title: Bambi (1942)
path_5.feeling: Tender and lyrical, a woodland heartache that still stirs me.

path_5.title: His Girl Friday (1940)

path_5.feeling: Amiable, songy shenanigans that go down easy if not memorably.

path_5.feeling: A cozy, clever caper with just enough fizz to satisfy.

path_5.title: Apartment, The (1960)
path_5.feeling: Bittersweet and adult, with sharp observations on love and compromise.

path_5.feeling: Genial and warmhearted, if a touch broad for my taste.
